Award.AwardTitle: Planning IUCRC Oakland University Center for Digital Joining and Repair
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a planning workshop for a new Industry-University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) aimed at improving composite material joining and repair (CJAR). Composite materials are vital to the health and competitiveness of several important economic sectors, including automotive, manufacturing, energy, and aerospace. As composites have different compositions and element concentration/orientation and tolerances that vary widely, current CJAR practices are highly specialized, labor-intensive, and require experienced technicians to complete the work successfully and reliably. Partner institutions Oakland University, Georgia Institute of Technology, and the University of Tennessee-Knoxville will work collaboratively with both the civilian and defense industries, in the automotive, aerospace, and energy sectors of the US economy. The Oakland University D-CJAR will primarily work with firms in the automotive (GM, Ford, Fiat Chrysler, BMW, General Dynamics Land Systems), manufacturing (John Deere), and civil aircraft engine (Pratt & Whitney) industries, and also with the National Center for Manufacturing Sciences and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. Faculty and student teams at the partner universities will work with industry members to develop and disseminate basic and applied precompetitive research on methodologies, technologies, tools, and workforce innovations to facilitate rapid, reliable, and cost-effective composite joining and repair, with an overall goal of reducing costs, cycle time, and variation of CJAR operations within 10 years.

The scope of work for the Oakland University D-CJAR center will include components of automotive, aircraft, infrastructure (wind turbine blades, etc.) and protective equipment that are wholly or partially made with composite materials, with the goal of transforming the current labor-intensive and specialized processes into science-based, automated, digital CJAR processes. We expect advances in several fields and knowledge domains around CJAR, including (1) design and analysis, (2) materials and process engineering, (3) testing and NDE, and (4) data analytics. We will apply diverse advanced digital techniques, including advanced computational modeling, sensing, materials characterization, and machine learning to practical CJAR cases that will also advance the education and workforce preparedness of students working on projects at the partner universities. Development of new materials and processes would facilitate standardization, modeling, and automation of many CJAR tasks and processes, producing cost savings, faster cycle times, and enhanced performance for industry partners across the entire composites supply chain, contributing to the maintenance of U.S. global leadership in this growing sector.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF Planning Grant award to Oakland University supports a planning workshop for a new Industry-University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) for Digital Composite Joining and Repair (D-CJAR) site with an Automotive-thrust, in close collaboration with Georgia Tech and the University of Tennessee-Knoxville, who would each have a respective site of D-CJAR; GT site with Aerospace thrust, and UTK site with Energy and Infrastructure thrust.    

Subsequent to grant award to Oakland University, the following deliverables have been accomplished by the PI, Co-Pi, and key research faculty and students at Oakland University, during the performance period from Sept. 1, 2018 to August 31, 2019:

1- Participation in Bootcamp training at NSF headquarters

Key personnel (PI and Co-PI) travelled to, and received bootcamp training from, NSF program

directors and consultants at NSF headquarters in Alexandria, VA on Oct.29-30, 2018.

 

2- Customer Discovery Effort and Value Proposition Development and Validation  

Subsequent to receiving NSF Bootcamp training, the PI and Co-PI at Oakland University worked closely with  their counterparts at GT and UTK, under the guidance of future NSF monitor and external consultants for 90-day-long customer discovery process that engaged more than 95 US industrial and government agency partners in the Automotive, Aerospace, and energy/infrastructure sectors.  That customer discovery process led to  successful development and test-validation of  a value proposition for the proposed sites of D-CJAR, in order to:   

 

  • ??Offer opportunities to collaborate on developing and gaining access to pre-competitive and cutting-edge technologies via D-CJAR projects and leverage industry dollars by sponsorship from other industry partners and NSF (with very a low overhead rate);
  • ?Provide cost-effective access to state-of-the-art R&D facilities and testbeds within the D-CJAR Center;
  • Identify workforce training requirements in the important area and opportunities to interact with potential employees by working with D-CJAR sponsored students;
  • Provide a CJAR technology repository and technology investment priority guide via D-CJAR technology roadmaps; and
  • Offer networking opportunities to interact and collaborate with other leaders in the CJAR community.?

 

3- Recruitment of 10 OU Industrial Delegates at the IUCRC Planning meeting  

 

Out of the 34 companies who participated in OU Customer discovery effort, 10 industrial

delegates have travelled as part of the Oakland University contingency that participated in the

March 5-6, 2019 NSF Planning meeting/workshop at Georgia Tech in Atlanta, GA.

 

4- Planning for and Participation in the IUCRC Planning meeting at GT on March 5-6, 2019

 

-        Developing agenda, heading OU delegation of key faculty researchers, students, industry to the Planning meeting.

-        Developing and presenting sample research projects to a wider industrial participants, NSF program director, and external program monitor.  

-        Responding to, and incorporating of, LIFE input to NSF at the Planning meeting.

 

5- Pre-Proposal Development and Submission for Phase 1 of ICURC at Oakland University

    (for a D-CJAR Center with an Automotive Thrust)

 

Subsequent to the NSF Planning meeting on March 5-6, 2018 and LIFE input, the OU PI                    Co-PI have accomplished the following tasks:

 

  • Developed and submitted Phase 1 Pre-proposal to NSF on for Phase 1 of IUCRC D-CJAR site at Oakland University (April 2019).
  • Secured financial commitment from 6 companies towards NSF-mandated Industrial Advisory Board (IAB): May-June 2019

 

6- Full Proposal Development and Submission for Phase 1 of ICURC at Oakland University

  • Per NSF encouragement, the OU PI and Co-PI developed and submitted Phase 1 full Proposal to NSF (in June 2019).  That is to establish an  IUCRC with a D-CJAR center site with Automotive Thrust at Oakland University, in close coordination with 2 partnering universities (GT and UTK), who separately submitted Phase 1 proposals for their respective sites of D-CJA with respective thrusts in Aerospace and Energy/Infrastructure.  

 

7- Budget Expenditure

 

This planning grant award is $15,000; the full amount was completely spent on authorized business  travel of 10 OU research faculty and students to and from grant-related meetings and activities, as itemized below:  

$2,600   Travel to NSF for bootcamp training for:

 Sayed Nassar (PI)

 Lian Yang (Co-PI)

$7,400  Travel to NSF Planning meeting at Georgia Tech (5 faculty + 3 students: named below)

Sayed Nassar (PI)

Lian Yang (Co-PI)

Roman Dembinski (key faculty researcher)

Khalid Malik (key faculty researcher)

Y. Geoffry  Louie (key faculty researcher)

Marco Gerini (Ph.D. student)

Shraddha Jagatap (Ph.D. student)

Mathew Berczyk (undergraduate student)

$5,000 Indirect Cost charges (on above travel expense)

_____________ 

$15,000     Total Grant Expense 

 


Last Modified: 11/06/2019
Modified by: Sayed Nassar
